original_summary: Todd didn't know Susan was taking over the Silk Company account which Todd has been on. Susan feels sorry.

transformed_conversations.personal_summary:
Here's a summary of your interactions with Susan regarding the Silk Company account, Todd. The situation first came to light on March 12th when Susan informed you out of the blue that she was taking over the account you had been working on for a month and a half. Apparently this decision was made the previous week without your knowledge while you were meeting with the client, Mr. Wei. 

Over the following weeks, you expressed your frustration to Susan and tried to get clarity on why the decision was made. In early April, about 3 weeks after first learning of the change, you had a lengthy discussion with Susan where she provided more context - apparently Mr. Emory, your boss, felt things were moving too slowly and wanted a "fresh start", but failed to inform you directly. While this provided some insight, you still felt slighted.

As spring progressed, you mostly moved on but the issue came up again in May when you were accidentally left off a key meeting invite regarding the Silk account. This resurfaced some of the earlier communication and process issues. You had a pointed conversation with Susan in late May where you re-emphasized the need for better communication and inclusion going forward.

Now, in mid-July, the Silk account transition occurred over 4 months ago. While there are still occasional frustrations, you've mostly settled into the new normal and are focused on other accounts. Susan has made efforts to improve communication and keep you in the loop, but it remains an area for continued growth. Looking back, while the initial handling was far from ideal, you're doing your best to be professional and move forward productively.

messages.content: You: Susan! Why didn't you tell me that you were taking over the Silk Company account?
Susan: I thought you knew, Todd. It was decided last week. I guess you weren't at the meeting.
You: You know I wasn't at the meeting. I was meeting with Mr. Wei about this account. I've been on this for a month and a half.
Susan: I'm sorry Todd, but Mr. Emory felt that it was going too slowly, and that it needed a fresh start. He should have told you.
You: I can't believe this. I've put so much work into this account already. Why wouldn't Mr. Emory talk to me directly?
Susan: I don't know, Todd. I was surprised too when he asked me to take over. I assumed you were in the loop. I should have double checked with you first.
You: Hey Susan, can we talk more about the Silk account transition? I'm still unclear on some of the details and reasoning.
Susan: Sure Todd, I'm free now if you want to grab a conference room.

You: Thanks for taking the time to go through everything, Susan. I'm still frustrated with how it was handled, but I appreciate you providing more context about Mr. Emory's thought process, even if I disagree with it.
Susan: I completely understand your frustration, Todd. For what it's worth, I think you were doing a good job with the account. I'll do my best to build on the great work you started.
You: Susan, I just saw that there was a Silk account strategy meeting this morning that I wasn't invited to. What's that about?
Susan: Oh no, that was my mistake, Todd. I'm sorry, I thought I had added you to the invite list but I must have forgotten. That's on me.
You: This keeps happening though. I'm still getting left out of key discussions and decisions on an account that I put a lot of time into. We need to figure out a better system.
Susan: You're absolutely right, I'll own that. Let me sync with Mr. Emory on how to make sure the right people are always in the loop going forward. It won't happen again.
You: Thanks Susan. I know we're all busy but this communication breakdown has been an ongoing issue. Let's prioritize getting it resolved.

Susan: Hey Todd, I just wanted to let you know that the Silk account renewed for another year. I know the transition was rocky, but I think we're on a good path now. I appreciate you bearing with me the last few months.
You: That's great news about the renewal, congrats Susan. You're right, it hasn't always been smooth sailing but I appreciate the efforts you've made to improve communication since we last talked.

Susan: Thanks Todd. I know I still have room for improvement but I'm committed to making sure you and the rest of the team are always kept informed and included going forward. Your contributions haven't gone unnoticed.
You: I appreciate you saying that, Susan. Water under the bridge at this point - let's just keep focusing on doing good work for our clients. I'm always happy to help where I can.
